results.title: Yankee doodle dandy
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, William Cagney and Michael Curtiz
results.brief_description: George B. Cohan, born on the 4th of July, became one of Broadway’s legendary composers. Cohan’s prolific career spanned 55 years where he wrote 35 plays and 500 songs including “Harrigan”, “Give my regards to Broadway”, and of course “Yankee Doodle Dandy.” This is an exuberant song and dance production starring James Cagney, with his typical flair, in the title role. This film premiered in 1942 and was a salute to American patriotism and the ‘Grand old flag’, yet time has not dulled its freshness and energy.

results.title: Yanis and his dream
results.creator_credit: Amitai Film Productions and Ami Amitai
results.brief_description: The story of a twelve-year-old boy living on the Greek island of Corfu in a small farming village, and his desire to leave the land and become a man of the sea.

results.title: Yani's Monkeys
results.creator_credit: Third Eye Productions, China Film and Channel 4 Television Corporation
results.brief_description: Yani, who lives in south-west Ching, started painting when she was 2 and a half years old. Her specialty is monkeys. Although still only a child, she is becoming famous throughout the world. The film shows her unique talent through past and present paintings and shows her brush technique by watching her at work.

results.title: Yangtze to Shangri-La
results.creator_credit: Grainger Television Australia and Greg Grainger
results.brief_description: Join Greg Grainger as he explores China in the new millenium, sailing from bustling Shanghai, up the Yangtze River, in search of the mythical kingdom of Shangri-La. Experience face-to-face encounters with Pandas, and the colourful ethnic minorities of Yunnan province, with a concert of music, centuries old, performed by 80 year old maestros. Also see teams of workers carving a two million dollar jade sculpture and a military spectacle in the City of Nanjing to celebrate National Day.

results.title: Yamaha fish stall = Ya Ma Ha yu dang
results.creator_credit: Pearl River Film Studio and Zhang Liang
results.brief_description:
The film depicts the impact of China’s economic reform on ordinary people in the early 1980s. Ah Long is a jobless young man who is recently set free from the jail. Wanting to start a new life, Ah Long sold all his valuables such as watch, TV and radio, and borrowed some money from friends in order to open a fish stall. He bought a Yamaha motor bike and asked his girlfriend Zhuzhu and another friend Haizai to join in. They name their small stall, Yamaha Fish Stall and are full of hope for their business. However, all Ah Long cares about is money and sometimes he even tricks his clients. This damages their reputation and the fish stall has to be closed. The three broke up and Zhuzhu’s mother wants her to marry a young man from Macau. Ah Long lost direction for life again and felt depressed. However, at this time, Ah Long’s competitor, Kui Mei gives Ah Long a helping hand by inviting him to join her fish stall. Kui Mei and her father’s trust makes Ah Long rethink about his past and helps him regain confidence. Ah Long found Haizai and his girlfriend Zhuzhu back and the three re-opened their fish stall and are all full of hope for life.

The story of the film takes place in China’s Guangdong province. Guangdong is the forerunner of China’s economic reform and remains as the country’s economic powerhouse today. Self-employment was a new concept in the early 1980s and there were heated debates on whether this belonged to socialist or capitalist economy.

This is a good film to gain insights into the early period of China’s economic reform. It gives the audience an idea of how the country’s planned economy is gradually shifting to a market-oriented economy. This is an interesting film for anyone who would like to make a comparison between China in the early 1980s and today’s China. (3 stars - Yuxing Zhou; May 21, 2010)

results.title: Yackety Yack
results.brief_description: A classic Australian underground comedy in which a group of people fight over how to make the truly collective/revolutionary/existential movie. Original intentions get sidetracked but all attempts to set things straight result in yet another, but strangely similar, script. Cast includes: John Flaus, Peggy Cole.

results.title: Yaaba
results.creator_credit: Heima Film, Les Films de L'Avenir, Arcadia Films, Pierre-Alain Meier, Idrissa Ouédraogo, Freddy Denaes and Michel David
results.brief_description: Few films are as fresh and simple as “Yaaba”, even fewer come as close to perfection. Set in a few flat, sunbaked hectares around a village in Burkina Faso the story is told with the directness of fable with little dialogue, and with the four-square photography confined to three colours - brown, blue and green. The central generation gap story is enriched with incidents of village life so that a vast range of human behaviour and experience is packed in without any sense of haste or padding. The result is not an example of naive cinema but a film whose technical and aesthetic sophistication is presented with an uncloying charm.

results.title: Ya Vamos. No. 1. A Mexico
results.creator_credit: Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Joshua Tree Productions
results.brief_description: A Spanish language film. Provides some cultural background of Mexico to students learning elementary Spanish with the text “entender y hablar”. Shows Lucia Sznchez and Sara Lopez travelling throughout Mexico.

results.title: XXX
results.creator_credit: Revolution Studios, Neil H Neil H. Moritz and Rob Cohen
results.brief_description: Director Rob Cohen’s second outing with action star Vin Diesel (their first collaboration was the very successful The Fast and the furious) is a playful hybrid of the James Bond spy movies and extreme sports action. Diesel stars as adrenaline junky Xander Cage who is coerced by the US government into infiltrating a Russian crime ring based in the Czech republic that is planning, amongst other things, the destruction of the world. XXX makes no secret of its Bond appropriations. Cohen gleefully includes in the mix an evil genius based in an elaborate (and not very conspicuous) mountain lair, a beautiful but dangerous woman (Asia Argento), Russian bad guys (yes they’re still bad, irregardless of the Cold War being over), state of the art gizmos and plenty of explosions. It even alludes to the beginnings of a long standing franchise. Cast includes: Samuel L. Jackson, Marton Csokas.
